awd_abstract_narration:
Archaea often thrive in extreme environments that accelerate DNA damage. There is a lack of comprehensive understanding of the molecular features that impart extreme resistance to DNA damage exhibited by many Archaea. This project aims to resolve the processes that maintain, replicate and repair the genome of the model archaeon Thermococcus kodakarensis. The focus is on elucidating unknown fitness benefits, specificities, rates and mechanisms underlying many archaeal DNA repair pathways. The outcomes will help clarify how DNA lesions are recognized and repaired, and how replication proceeds on lesion-containing DNAs in archaea and other organisms. The project provides research training and career development opportunities for students at all levels, including undergraduate and high school students, notably with immersive research experiences in academic, private and federal laboratories. 

The project will employ a scaled approach, from purified enzyme kinetics in vitro to whole cell phenotypic assays and growth measurements. Novel, high-throughput assays will be used to probe mechanisms of archaeal DNA repair, discover new repair factors and establish the contributions of different DNA polymerases to DNA repair. Examination of multiple DNA repair and replicative pathways by complementary experimental techniques will yield a comprehensive mechanistic view of archaeal DNA repair and how the pathways collectively impart fitness to these organisms in extreme environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Results of prior NSF support

Award #2016857; Archaeal DNA Repair; 08/01/2020-07/31/2024 (including NCE)

 

Intellectual accomplishments/deliverables. We achieved success for each major goal of each aim, presented our studies at regional, national, and international venues, and published 6 new manuscripts acknowledging funding from the award period.. The goals of the award did not change during the funding period (2020-23; no cost extension granted in 2024). No adjustments to our timeline were warranted given continued positive progress. Given that new ideas and new technologies demand timely experimental investigations, in addition to the original aims, we were simultaneously able to i) radically improve (3-orders of magnitude) the transformation efficiency of Thermococcus kodakarensis through elimination of host-defense systems, opening up entirely new genetic potential now that ~1/1000 cells can be transformed, ii) define the fitness and mutational impact due to deletion of newly identified factors that prevent DNA damage by cleansing the (d)NTP pool, iii) initiated investigations into the molecular basis of how some DNA repair factors recognize and even favor RNA for catalysis, iv) generated and screened large fosmid libraries for new DNA repair enzymes, combining predictive and comparative AI techniques, including publishing on a new enzyme identified via such techniques, v) identified and initially characterized – in vitroand in vivo – two new candidates for novel mechanisms of direct DNA repair (a putative aminase and a novel photolyase), vi) defined the contributions of homologous recombination in DNA repair and replication mechanisms, and vii) gained access to massive archaeal-rich sequencing datasets that we are actively mining for additional novel archaeal-encoded chemistries that monitor and repair the genome.

 

The focus for our research program is unchanged: to identify novel archaeal-encoded chemistries that recognize and initiate DNA repair through rigorous enzymology and quantification of DNA repair rates in vitro coupled with complementary genetic techniques to establish the coordination, competition, and redundancy of the totality of DNA repair pathways that contribute to archaeal fitness. Our aims included: i) establishing techniques to map and quantify distinct forms of DNA damage across the entire genome, ii) defining and characterizing new base-excision repair enzymes and pathways, and iii) providing additional evidence in support of new mechanisms of DNA repair – including a nucleotide excision repair mechanism and putative new direct repair pathways – within the model species T. kodakarensis. During the funding period we identified, crystallized, and characterized – in vivo and in vitro – both a novel AP lyase (TK0353) and detailed a major oxidative damage base excision repair (BER) system conserved in the Archaea. We provided the most concrete evidence for the participation and requirements for 7 enzymes linked to a likely-novel archaeal nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway. We demonstrated that homologous recombination is a major DNA repair pathway, we established mechanisms to quantify the fitness consequences of removing enzymes that cleanse the dNTP pool, and we established a validated pipeline for the discovery of new BER enzymes.

 

Broader impacts from prior funding. We trained/are training 17 (seventeen) MS/PhD students: G Liman$, B Wenck$, T Sanders$, C Marshall$, S Williams$, K Scott/Fluke$; M Stettler#, B Musco#, G Cork#, J Selan#; L Betancurt*, A Alon*, A Galyon*, G Spalink*, P Ulisse*, L Elkins^, J Schiltz^ (PhD$ or MS# awarded ; PhD* or MS^ in progress), who together with research scientists/associates/post-docs (M Banco, K Rioux, P Caffrey, and B Burkhart), have moved the project from initial to publication stages. Assistance from 16 talented undergraduates and 5 high school student interns sped progress in all areas. Each trainee – at all levels – presented their data at regional, national, and international venues, and when compiled with thesis defenses, >100 public talks and posters were presented in the funding period. In addition to intense, monthly, virtual exchanges of new ideas and data, funding supported professional enrichment activities through the exchange and coordinated training of personnel between federal, private, non-profit, and academic communities. Each PI visited each site, and we coordinated a mid-project, in-person retreat at the National Institute of Standard and Technology (NIST), allowing all personnel to explore the NIST campus, equipment, and capabilities. Four trainees from CSU visited and trained at NIST and/or New England Biolabs (NEB), Inc.; one trainee from CSU is now employed at NEB, Inc. Attendance and presentation of the results obtained during the funding period at the Gordon Research Conference on Archaea and other major meetings in the field provided additional opportunities for consortium members to meet in person and drive progress. Co-PI Gardner transitioned during the funding period to become CSO of the Gloucester Marine Genomics Institute (GMGI). Our strong relationship with Zatopek at NEB, Inc. retained all resources from such, and the addition of resources from GMGI only bolstered progress and added excitement. 

 


Last Modified: 09/23/2024
Modified by: Thomas Santangelo
